name: gallery-examples
title: Vega Ecosystem Gallery Examples Registry
description: Cross-reference catalog mapping gallery examples to vega-datasets resources. Tracks which datasets from the vega-datasets collection are used in example visualizations across Vega, Vega-Lite, and Altair galleries.

examples.description: This example shows how to make a heatmap from binned quantitative data.
This example shows how to make a 2d histogram scatter plot.

`Anscombe's Quartet <https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Anscombe%27s_quartet>`_ is a famous dataset constructed by Francis Anscombe. It is made of 4 different subsets of data. Each subset has very different characteristics, even though common summary statistics such as mean and variance are identical. This example shows how to make a faceted plot, with each facet showing a different subset of the data.

This example shows how to make an area chart with a gradient fill. For more information about gradient options see the Vega-Lite `Gradient documentation <https://vega.github.io/vega-lite/docs/types.html#gradient>`_.
This example is a fully developed line chart that uses a window transformation. It was inspired by `Gregor Aisch's work at datawrapper <https://www.datawrapper.de/_/OHgEm/>`_.

examples.example_name: Bar Chart Highlighting Values beyond a Threshold
examples.description: This example shows a bar chart highlighting values beyond a threshold.
This example shows a basic bar chart with a single bar highlighted.
This example shows a bar chart that highlights values beyond a threshold.

examples.example_name: Bar Chart with Highlighting on Hover and Selection on Click
examples.description: This example shows a bar chart with highlighting on hover and selecting on click. (Inspired by Tableau's interaction style.) Based on https://vega.github.io/vega-lite/examples/interactive_bar_select_highlight.html
This example shows a basic horizontal bar chart with labels created with Altair.

examples.example_name: Bar Chart with Labels based on Measured Luminance
examples.description: This example shows a basic horizontal bar chart with labels where the measured luminance to decides if the text overlay is be colored ``black`` or ``white``.

examples.example_name: Bar Chart with Line at Mean
examples.description: This example shows the mean value overlaid on a bar chart.

examples.example_name: Bar Chart with Line on Dual Axis
examples.description: This example shows how to combine two plots and keep their axes. For a more polished version of this chart, see :ref:`gallery_wheat_wages`.
This example shows a bar chart with both positive and negative values.
This example shows a range bar chart where each bar displays information of a low and high value.
A bar chart overlaid with a rolling mean. In this example the average of values over the previous decade is displayed as a line.
This example shows how to create a bar chart with rounded edges.
How to layer a tick chart on top of a bar chart.

The example demonstrates the faceted charts created by Richard Becker, William Cleveland and others in the 1990s. Using the visualization technique where each row is a different site (i.e. the chart is faceted by site), they identified an anomaly in a widely used agriculatural dataset, where the "Morris" site accidentally had the years 1931 and 1932 swapped. They named this `"The Morris Mistake." <http://ml.stat.purdue.edu/stat695t/writings/Trellis.User.pdf>`_.

The example demonstrates the faceted charts created by Richard Becker, William Cleveland and others in the 1990s. Using the visualization technique where each row is a different site (i.e. the chart is faceted by site), they identified an anomaly in a widely used agriculatural dataset, where the "Morris" site accidentally had the years 1931 and 1932 swapped. They named this `"The Morris Mistake." <http://ml.stat.purdue.edu/stat695t/writings/Trellis.User.pdf>`_.

This example shows how to make a boxplot using US Population data from 2000. Note that the default value of the `extent` property is 1.5, which represents the convention of extending the whiskers to the furthest points within 1.5 * IQR from the first and third quartile.

examples.example_name: Brushing Scatter Plot to Show Data on a Table
examples.description: A scatter plot of the cars dataset, with data tables for horsepower, MPG, and origin. The tables update to reflect the selection on the scatter plot.
This example shows how to make a bubble plot.
This example shows a bump chart. The data is first grouped into six-month intervals using pandas. The ranks are computed by Altair using a window transform.

A dot plot showing each movie in the database, and the difference from the average movie rating. The display is sorted by year to visualize everything in sequential order. The graph is for all Movies before 2019. Adapted from `Calculate Residuals <https://vega.github.io/vega-lite/examples/joinaggregate_residual_graph.html>`_.
This chart demonstrates how to use a joinaggregate transform to display data values as a percentage of total.

A candlestick chart inspired from `Protovis <http://mbostock.github.io/protovis/ex/candlestick.html>`_. This example shows the performance of the Chicago Board Options Exchange `Volatility Index <https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/VIX>`_ (VIX) in the summer of 2009. The thick bar represents the opening and closing prices, while the thin bar shows intraday high and low prices; if the index closed higher on a given day, the bars are colored green rather than red.
A choropleth map of unemployment rate per county in the US

Inspired by `Zan Armstrong's comet chart <https://www.zanarmstrong.com/infovisresearch>`_ this plot uses ``mark_trail`` to visualize change of grouped data over time. A more elaborate example and explanation of creating comet charts in Altair is shown in `this blogpost <https://medium.com/de-dataverbinders/comet-charts-in-python-visualizing-statistical-mix-effects-and-simpsons-paradox-with-altair-6cd51fb58b7c>`_.

examples.example_name: Compact Faceted Grid of Bar Charts
examples.description: A simple grid of bar charts to compare performance data, one subchart for each subset of the data.

This example shows bivariate deviation ellipses of petal length and width of three iris species. Inspired by `ggplot2.stat_ellipse`_ and directly based on `Deviation ellipses example`_ by `@essicolo`_ .. _ggplot2.stat_ellipse: https://ggplot2.tidyverse.org/reference/stat_ellipse.html#ref-examples .. _Deviation ellipses example: https://github.com/vega/altair/pull/514 .. _@essicolo: https://github.com/essicolo

This example shows all the connections between major U.S. airports. Lookup transformations are used to find the coordinates of each airport and connecting airports. Connections are displayed on pointerover via a single selection.
This example shows an area chart with cumulative count. Adapted from https://vega.github.io/vega-lite/examples/area_cumulative_freq.html
This is a dendrogram from the result of a hierarchical clustering. It's based on the example from https://scikit-learn.org/stable/auto_examples/cluster/plot_agglomerative_dendrogram.html

examples.example_name: Distributions and Medians of Likert Scale Ratings
examples.description: Distributions and Medians of Likert Scale Ratings. (Figure 9 from @jhoffswell and @zcliu’s ‘Interactive Repair of Tables Extracted from PDF Documents on Mobile Devices’ – http://idl.cs.washington.edu/files/2019-InteractiveTableRepair-CHI.pdf). Adapted from `Distributions and Medians of Likert Scale Ratings <https://vega.github.io/vega-lite/examples/layer_likert.html>`_.
This example shows a diverging stacked bar chart for sentiments towards a set of eight questions, displayed as percentages with neutral responses straddling the 0% mark.
This example shows how to make a Donut Chart using ``mark_arc``. This is adapted from a corresponding Vega-Lite Example: `Donut Chart <https://vega.github.io/vega-lite/examples/arc_donut.html>`_.

How to make the dot-dash plot presented in Edward Tufte's `Visual Display of Quantitative Information <https://www.edwardtufte.com/tufte/books_vdqi>`_. Based on a JavaScript implementation by `g3o2 <https://bl.ocks.org/g3o2/bd4362574137061c243a2994ba648fb8>`_.
This example shows an empirical cumulative distribution function.

This example shows how to show error bars using confidence intervals. The confidence intervals are computed internally in vega by a non-parametric `bootstrap of the mean <https://github.com/vega/vega-statistics/blob/master/src/bootstrapCI.js>`_.
This example shows how to show error bars with standard deviation using crop yields data of different in the years of 1930s.
Multiple area subcharts, one for each company. We also show filtering out one of the companies, and sorting the companies in a custom order.

A set of maps arranged in a grid, each showing the distribution of a species' projected habitat across US counties. Each choropleth map uses color intensity to represent the percentage values within county boundaries.

This example shows how to make a basic faceted histogram, with one histogram subplot for different subsets of the data. Based off the vega-lite example: https://vega.github.io/vega-lite/examples/trellis_bar_histogram.html

examples.example_name: Faceted Line Chart with Cumulative Sum
examples.description: This chart creates one facet per natural disaster and shows the cumulative number of deaths for that category. Note the use of different predicates to filter based on both a list and a range.
A series of scatter plots, one for each country/area of origin.
A horizontal stacked bar chart using barley crop yield data. The chart is horizontally faceted based on the year, and vertically faceted based on variety.
This example shows Google's stock price over time as a step chart with its area filled in and its line emphasized.
This example shows how to make a simple Gantt chart.

This example shows how to make a bubble plot showing the correlation between health and income for 187 countries in the world (modified from an example in Lisa Charlotte Rost's blog post `'One Chart, Twelve Charting Libraries' <http://lisacharlotterost.github.io/2016/05/17/one-chart-code/>`_.
This example shows a proportional symbols visualization of deaths from natural disasters by year and type.
This example shows a grouped bar chart.

examples.example_name: Grouped Bar Chart with Error Bars
examples.description: This example shows a grouped bar chart with error bars.

Like :ref:`gallery_grouped_bar_chart`, this example shows a grouped bar chart. Whereas :ref:`gallery_grouped_bar_chart` used the ``column`` encoding channel, this example uses the ``xOffset`` encoding channel. This is adapted from a corresponding Vega-Lite Example: `Grouped Bar Chart <https://vega.github.io/vega-lite/examples/bar_grouped.html>`_.

examples.example_name: Grouped Bar Chart with xOffset and overlapping bars
examples.description: Like :ref:`gallery_grouped_bar_chart2`, this example shows a grouped bar chart using the ``xOffset`` encoding channel, but in this example the bars are partly overlapping within each group.

examples.example_name: Grouped Points with Proportional Symbols Map
examples.description: This is a layered geographic visualization that groups points by state.

This example shows how to make an alternative form of a histogram `designed at Google <https://www.smashingmagazine.com/2022/07/accessibility-first-approach-chart-visual-design/>`_ with the goal of increasing accessibility.
This example shows a hexbin chart.
This example shows how to make a histogram with gradient color. The low-high IMDB rating is represented with the color scheme `pinkyellowgreen`.
This shows an example of a histogram with bins that are responsive to a selection domain. Click and drag on the bottom panel to see the bins change on the top panel.

examples.example_name: Histogram with a Global Mean Overlay
examples.description: This example shows a histogram with a global mean overlay.
This example shows how to make a Horizon Graph with 2 layers. (See https://idl.cs.washington.edu/papers/horizon/ for more details on Horizon Graphs.)
This example is a bar chart drawn horizontally by putting the quantitative value on the x axis.
This example shows a horizontal grouped bar chart.
This is an example of a horizontal stacked bar chart using data which contains crop yields over different regions and different years in the 1930s.

The plot below uses an interval selection, which causes the chart to include an interactive brush (shown in grey). The brush selection parameterizes the red guideline, which visualizes the average value within the selected interval.

This example shows an interactive chart where the range binder controls a threshold as rule where the datapoints on the left-side are aggregated and on the right-side are drawn as is. The ability to slide back and fourth may help you understand how the visualization represents the aggregation. Adapted from an example by @dwootton.

This example shows an interactive chart where selections in one portion of the chart affect what is shown in other panels. Click on the bar chart to see a detail of the distribution in the upper panel.
This example shows a multi-panel view of the same data, where you can interactively select a portion of the data in any of the panels to highlight that portion in any of the other panels.

The following shows how to create a chart with an interactive legend, by binding the selection to ``"legend"``. Such a binding only works with ``selection_point`` when projected over a single field or encoding.
This example shows how to add a simple rectangular brush to a scatter plot. By clicking and dragging on the plot, you can highlight points within the range.

examples.example_name: Interactive Scatter Plot and Linked Layered Histogram
examples.description: This example shows how to link a scatter plot and a histogram together such that clicking on a point in the scatter plot will isolate the distribution corresponding to that point, and vice versa.

This example shows how columns can be selected interactively by accessing the values from selector widgets, and then compute the difference of the selected columns. It also illustrates how to use `indexof` to filter columns based on active selection values.
This is an example of a binned bar chart on the right where the filtered overlay is adjusted by interacting with the map on the left.

examples.example_name: Interval Selection with Initial Date Range
examples.description: This is an example of creating a stacked chart for which the domain of the top chart can be selected by interacting with the bottom chart. The initial selection range is set using Python's native datetime objects.
This example is a fully developed stacked chart using the sample dataset of Iowa's electricity sources.

Isotype Visualization shows the distribution of animals across UK and US. Inspired by `Only An Ocean Between, 1943 <http://www.thomwhite.co.uk/?p=1303>`_. Population Live Stock, p.13. This is adapted from Vega-Lite example https://vega.github.io/editor/#/examples/vega-lite/isotype_bar_chart

Isotype Visualization shows the distribution of animals across UK and US, using unicode emoji marks rather than custom SVG paths (see https://altair-viz.github.io/gallery/isotype.html). This is adapted from Vega-Lite example https://vega.github.io/vega-lite/examples/isotype_bar_chart_emoji.html.
This example is a grid of isotype figures.
This example shows a layered area chart.
This example shows a segmented bar chart that is layered rather than stacked.
This example shows how to use opacity to make a layered histogram in Altair.
This example shows how to create a second independent y axis.

This example shows a simple line chart with two types of arrow annotations. The Unicode character approach is simpler, while the line plus triangle :ref:`point mark <user-guide-point-marks>` allows for greater flexibility, such as customizable arrowheads.

examples.example_name: Line Chart with Confidence Interval Band
examples.description: How to make a line chart with a bootstrapped 95% confidence interval band.
This chart creates a simple line chart from the cumulative sum of a fields.
This example uses the argmax aggregation function in order to create a custom legend for a line chart.

By default, the line's path (order of points in the line) is determined by data values on the temporal/ordinal field. However, a field can be mapped to the order channel for a custom path. For example, to show a pattern of data change over time between gasoline price and average miles driven per capita we use order channel to sort the points in the line by time field (year). The earliest year (1956) is one endpoint and the latest year (2010) is the other endpoint. This is based on Hannah Fairfield's article 'Driving Shifts Into Reverse'. See https://archive.nytimes.com/www.nytimes.com/imagepages/2010/05/02/business/02metrics.html.

An example of using ``datum`` to highlight certain values, including a ``DateTime`` value. This is adapted from two corresponding Vega-Lite Examples: `Highlight a Specific Value <https://vega.github.io/vega-lite/docs/datum.html#highlight-a-specific-data-value>`_.

examples.example_name: Line Chart with Datum for Color
examples.description: An example of using ``repeat`` inside ``datum`` to color a multi-series line chart. This is adapted from this corresponding Vega-Lite Example: `Repeat and Layer to Show Different Movie Measures <https://vega.github.io/vega-lite/examples/repeat_layer.html>`_.

This chart shows a line chart with the path interpolated. A full list of interpolation methods is available `in the documentation <https://altair-viz.github.io/user_guide/generated/core/altair.LineConfig.html?highlight=interpolate#altair-lineconfig>`_.

examples.example_name: Line Chart with Last Value Labeled
examples.description: This chart shows a line chart with a label annotating the final value

This example shows how to make a multi-series line chart of the daily closing stock prices for AAPL, AMZN, GOOG, IBM, and MSFT between 2000 and 2010, along with a layered rule showing the average values.
How to make a line chart on a `Logarithmic scale <https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Logarithmic_scale>`_.
This example shows how to format the tick labels of the y-axis of a chart as percentages.
This chart shows a simple line chart with points marking each value.
This examples shows how to create multiple lines using the sequence generator.

examples.example_name: Line Chart with Stroked Point Markers
examples.description: This example shows a simple line chart with points in a different color.
This is example of using the ``trail`` marker to vary the size of a line.

This example shows the London tube lines against the background of the borough boundaries. It is based on the vega-lite example at https://vega.github.io/vega-lite/examples/geo_layer_line_london.html.

This multi-line chart uses an invisible Voronoi tessellation to handle pointerover to identify the nearest point and then highlight the line on which the point falls. It is adapted from the Vega-Lite example found at https://bl.ocks.org/amitkaps/fe4238e716db53930b2f1a70d3401701

This example shows how you can use selections and layers to create a tooltip-like behavior tied to the x position of the cursor. If you are looking for more standard tooltips, see the :ref:`gallery_multiline_tooltip_standard` example. In this example, we'll employ a little trick to isolate the x-position of the cursor: we add some transparent points with only an x encoding (no y encoding) and tie a *nearest* selection to these, tied to the "x" field.

This example shows how to add a standard tooltip to the same chart as in :ref:`gallery_multiline_tooltip`. You can find another example using this approach in the documentation on the :ref:`user-guide-pivot-transform` transformation.

examples.example_name: Multi-panel Scatter Plot with Linked Brushing
examples.description: This is an example of using an interval selection to control the color of points across multiple panels.
This example shows how to make a scatter plot with multiple feature encodings.

This example shows how multiple user inputs can be layered onto a chart. The four inputs have functionality as follows: * Dropdown: Filters the movies by genre * Radio Buttons: Highlights certain films by Worldwide Gross * Mouse Drag and Scroll: Zooms the x and y scales to allow for panning * Checkbox: Scales the marker size of big budget films
This example shows how to make a line chart with multiple series of data.

A `Parallel Coordinates <https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Parallel_coordinates>`_ chart is a chart that lets you visualize the individual data points by drawing a single line for each of them. Such a chart can be created in Altair by first transforming the data into a suitable representation. This example shows a modified parallel coordinates chart with the Iris dataset, where the y-axis shows the value after min-max rather than the raw value. It's a simplified Altair version of `the VegaLite version <https://vega.github.io/vega-lite/examples/parallel_coordinate.html>`_
This example shows how to make a normalized stacked area chart.
This is an example of a normalized stacked bar chart using data which contains crop yields over different regions and different years in the 1930s.
This example shows a geographical plot with one dot per zipcode.
Chart made using ``mark_arc`` and constant values. This could also be made using ``alt.Chart(source).mark_arc(color = "gold", theta = (5/8)*np.pi, theta2 = (19/8)*np.pi,radius=100)``.

A `Parallel Coordinates <https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Parallel_coordinates>`_ chart is a chart that lets you visualize the individual data points by drawing a single line for each of them. Such a chart can be created in Altair by first transforming the data into a suitable representation. This example shows a parallel coordinates chart with the Iris dataset.
This example shows how to make a Pie Chart using ``mark_arc``. This is adapted from a corresponding Vega-Lite Example: `Pie Chart <https://vega.github.io/vega-lite/examples/arc_pie.html>`_.

This example shows how to layer text over arc marks (``mark_arc``) to label pie charts. This is adapted from a corresponding Vega-Lite Example: `Pie Chart with Labels <https://vega.github.io/vega-lite/examples/layer_arc_label.html>`_.
This is a layered map that shows the positions of airports on a background of U.S. states.

This example shows how to make a polar bar chart using ``mark_arc``. This could also have been called a "pie chart with axis labels", but is more commonly referred to as a polar bar chart. The axis lines are created using pie charts with only the stroke visible.

examples.example_name: Polynomial Fit Plot with Regression Transform
examples.description: This example shows how to overlay data with multiple fitted polynomials using the regression transform.
This example is a reproduction of the Falkensee plot found in the Vega-Lite examples.
Altair reproduction of http://robslink.com/SAS/democd91/pyramid_pie.htm
A quantile-quantile plot comparing input data to theoretical distributions.

This radial plot uses both angular and radial extent to convey multiple dimensions of data. This is adapted from a corresponding Vega-Lite Example: `Radial Plot <https://vega.github.io/vega-lite/examples/arc_radial.html>`_.
This example shows a ranged dot plot to convey changing life expectancy for the five most populous countries (between 1955 and 2000).

This example uses a calculate transform to check the values of the "site" column vs the clicked values in the legend, and assigns a lower order (0) if there is a match. The use of "indexOf" checks for equality in an array, which here allows for multiple segments to be reordered by holding down the shift key while clicking the legend.
Three choropleths representing disjoint data from the same table.
Density estimates for each feature of iris flower. This is what we call a "repeated" plot, with one subplot for each feature.

A `Ridgeline plot <https://serialmentor.com/blog/2017/9/15/goodbye-joyplots>`_ lets you visualize distribution of a numeric value for different subsets of data (what we call "facets" in Altair). Such a chart can be created in Altair by first transforming the data into a suitable representation.
An example of using a RepeatChart to construct a multi-panel scatter plot with linked panning and zooming.

examples.example_name: Scatter Plot and Histogram with Interval Selection
examples.description: This example shows how to link a scatter plot and a histogram together such that an interval selection in the histogram will plot the selected values in the scatter plot. Note that both subplots need to know about the `mbin` field created by the `transform_bin` method. In order to achieve this, the data is not passed to the `Chart()` instances creating the subplots, but directly in the `hconcat()` function, which joins the two plots together.

examples.example_name: Scatter Plot with Faceted Marginal Histograms
examples.description: This example demonstrates how to generate a scatter plot, with faceted marginal histograms that share their respective x- and y-limits.
This example shows a scatter plot with an ``href`` encoding constructed from the car name. With this encoding, you can click on any of the points to open a google search for the car name.
This example shows how to add a trend line to a scatter plot using the LOESS transform (LOcally Estimated Scatter Plot Smoothing).
This example shows how to create a miniature version of a plot such that creating a selection in the miniature version adjusts the axis limits in another, more detailed view.
A scatter plot with a rolling mean overlay. In this example a 30 day window is used to calculate the mean of the maximum temperature around each date.
This example shows a scatter plot with shaded area, constructed using :ref:`area mark <user-guide-area-marks>` and :ref:`rect mark <user-guide-rect-marks>`.

examples.example_name: Scatter plot with point paths on hover with search box
examples.description: This example combines cross-sectional analysis (comparing countries at a single point in time) with longitudinal analysis (tracking changes in individual countries over time), using an interactive visualization technique inspired by [this Vega example](https://vega.github.io/vega/examples/global-development/) Key features: 1. Point Paths. On hover, shows data trajectories using a trail mark that thickens from past to present, clearly indicating the direction of time. 2. Search Box. Implements a case-insensitive regex filter for country names, enabling dynamic, flexible data point selection to enhance exploratory analysis.

This chart provides an interactive exploration of Seattle weather over the course of the year. It includes a one-axis brush selection to easily see the distribution of weather types in a particular date range.

This example shows a selection that links two views of data: the left panel contains one point per object, and the right panel contains one line per object. Clicking on either the points or lines will select the corresponding objects in both views of the data. The challenge lies in expressing such hierarchical data in a way that Altair can handle. We do this by merging the data into a "long form" dataframe, and aggregating identical metadata for the final plot.
This chart shows an example of using an interval selection to filter the contents of an attached histogram, allowing the user to see the proportion of items in each category within the selection.

This example shows how to bring selected points to the front/foreground by using a condition to change the point's (z)order as it is hovered over with the pointer. This prevents that the selected points are obscured by those that are not selected.
This example shows a basic bar chart created with Altair.
This example shows a simple heatmap for showing gridded data.
This example shows how to make a basic histogram, based on the vega-lite docs https://vega.github.io/vega-lite/examples/histogram.html
This example shows how to make an interactive scatter plot.
This chart shows the most basic line chart, made from a dataframe with two columns.
A simple scatter plot of a data set with errorbars.
This example shows a basic scatter plot with labels created with Altair.
A scatter plot of the cars dataset, with tooltips showing selected column values when you hover over points. We make the points larger so that it is easier to hover over them.
This example shows how to make a simple stacked area chart.
A simple example of how to make a strip plot.

This example shows how to bind a variable parameter to a slider, and how to use the corresponding bound value to color data points. This example is based on an example from the Altair 4 documentation for Interactions, in which the interactivity was accomplished using a selection. The version below has been simplified significantly through the use of a variable parameter. Variable parameters were added in Altair 5.
This example shows how to make Slope Graph.
This example shows a bar chart sorted by a calculated value.

examples.example_name: Sorted Error Bars showing Confidence Interval
examples.description: This example shows how to show error bars using confidence intervals, while also sorting the y-axis based on x-axis values.
This is an example of a stacked bar chart using data which contains crop yields over different regions and different years in the 1930s.

examples.example_name: Stacked Bar Chart with Sorted Segments
examples.description: This is an example of a stacked-bar chart with the segments of each bar resorted.

examples.example_name: Stacked Bar Chart with Text Overlay
examples.description: This example shows how to overlay text on a stacked bar chart. For both the bar and text marks, we use the ``stack`` argument in the ``x`` encoding to cause the values to be stacked horizontally.

To plot a stacked graph of estimates, use a shared ``extent`` and a fixed number of subdivision ``steps`` to ensure that the points for each area align well. Density estimates of measurements for each iris flower feature are plot in a stacked method. In addition, setting ``counts`` to true multiplies the densities by the number of data points in each group, preserving proportional differences.
This example shows how to make a stem and leaf plot.

This example shows Google's stock price over time. This uses the "step-after" interpolation scheme. The full list of interpolation options includes 'linear', 'linear-closed', 'step', 'step-before', 'step-after', 'basis', 'basis-open', 'basis-closed', 'cardinal', 'cardinal-open', 'cardinal-closed', 'bundle', and 'monotone'.
This example shows the streamgraph from vega-lite examples.

In this chart, we encode the ``Major_Genre`` column from the ``movies`` dataset in the ``y``-channel. In the default presentation of this data, it would be difficult to gauge the relative frequencies with which different values occur because there would be so much overlap. To address this, we use the ``yOffset`` channel to incorporate a random offset (jittering). The example is shown twice, on the left side using normally distributed and on the right side using uniformally distributed jitter.
This example shows github contributions by the day of week and hour of the day.
An example of a layered chart of text over a heatmap using the cars dataset.

examples.example_name: The U.S. Employment Crash During the Great Recession
examples.description: This example is a fully developed bar chart with negative values using the sample dataset of U.S. employment changes during the Great Recession.
This example shows how to use the window and transformation filter to display the Top items of a long list of items in decreasing order. Here we sort the top 10 highest ranking movies of IMDB.

This example shows how to use a window transform in order to display only the top K categories by number of entries. In this case, we rank the characters in the first paragraph of Dickens' *A Tale of Two Cities* by number of occurrences.
This example shows how to use aggregate, window, and calculate transformations to display the top-k directors by average worldwide gross while grouping the remaining directors as 'All Others'.

examples.example_name: U.S. State Capitals Overlaid on a Map of the U.S
examples.description: This is a layered geographic visualization that shows US capitals overlaid on a map.

examples.example_name: US Income by State: Wrapped Facet
examples.description: This example shows how to create a map of income in the US by state, faceted over income brackets

examples.example_name: US Population by Age and Sex
examples.description: This chart visualizes the age distribution of the US population over time. It uses a slider widget that is bound to the year to visualize the age distribution over time.
This chart visualizes the age distribution of the US population over time, using a wrapped faceting of the data by decade.
A population pyramid shows the distribution of age groups within a population. It uses a slider widget that is bound to the year to visualize the age distribution over time.

Because area is considered one object, just using the plain selector will select the entire area instead of just one part of it. This example shows how to use two areas, one on top of the other, and a `transform_filter` to fake out this effect.
This example shows how to make a Violin Plot using Altair's density transform.
This example shows how to recreate a Vega-Lite implementation of a waterfall chart. Original inspiration is from https://vega.github.io/vega-lite/examples/waterfall_chart.html

A recreation of William Playfair's classic chart visualizing the price of wheat, the wages of a mechanic, and the reigning British monarch. This is a more polished version of the simpler chart in :ref:`gallery_bar_and_line_with_dual_axis`.
An example of a `Wilkinson Dot Plot <https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dot_plot_(statistics)>`_

An example showing a vector array map showing wind speed and direction using ``wedge`` as shape for ``mark_point`` and ``angle`` encoding for the wind direction. This is adapted from this corresponding Vega-Lite Example: `Wind Vector Map <https://vega.github.io/vega-lite/examples/point_angle_windvector.html>`_ with an added base map.
This example shows the Group F rankings in the 2018 World Cup after each matchday. A window transformation is used to rank each after each match day, sorting by points and difference.
This example shows how to create a world map using data generators for different background layers.

This example shows a map of the countries of the world. Use the dropdown menu to compare projections. For more details on the `project` arguments, see the API of `altair.Projection <https://altair-viz.github.io/user_guide/generated/core/altair.Projection.html>`_.
Interactive map of U.S. airport connections in 2008.
A plot of 2016 annual global precipitation data from the NOAA Climate Forecast System (CFS) v2.
Area charts showing average daily temperatures in Seattle for each hour of the day.
An arc diagram depicting character co-occurrence in the novel Les Misérables.
A basic area chart example.
A basic bar chart example, with value labels shown upon pointer hover.
An example of Vega visualization that automatically switches between a column chart and a line chart depending on the number of data points
A small multiples view of barley yields by site and variety.
A beeswarm chart example that uses a force-directed layout to group items by category.
A binned scatter plot example showing aggregate counts per binned cell.
A box plot example showing aggregate statistics for penguin body mass.
A scatter plot matrix of penguin data with interactive linked selections.
A recreation of a New York Times chart showing U.S. budget forecasts versus reality.
A calendar visualization of daily changes to the S&P 500 since 2000.
An example of a circle packing layout for hierarchical data.
A circular clock visualization showing the current time.
An example of a connected scatter plot, tracking changes in miles driven versus the price of gasoline.
A contour plot example, overlaying a density estimate on scatter plot points.
A choropleth map depicting U.S. unemployment rates by county in 2009.
Interactive cross-filtering among histograms of flight statistics.
A small multiples view of 2D density heatmaps of automobile statistics.
A map view comparing area distortions between two projections.
A basic donut chart example.
Donut with non-overlapping labels.
A Dorling cartogram depicting U.S. state obesity rates.
A dot plot example depicting the distribution of animal sleep times.
An interactive globe depicting earthquake locations and magnitudes.
Rotating globe animation depicting earthquake locations. Background - pseudorandomly distributed 'stars'.
A network diagram of software dependencies, with edges grouped via hierarchical edge bundling.
A basic error bar visualization example.
An annotated line chart of the population of Falkensee, Germany.
Passenger Traffic at Seattle-Tacoma International Airport, Percentage Change from October 2019 to March 2020
A node-link diagram with force-directed layout, depicting character co-occurrence in the novel Les Misérables.
An interactive scatter plot of global health statistics by country and year.
A basic grouped bar chart example.
A heatmap showing average daily temperatures in Seattle for each hour of the day.
An interactive histogram for visualizing a univariate distribution.
A histogram of film ratings, modified to include null values.
A horizon graph, which preserves resolution by layering slices of an area chart.
A hypothetical outcome plot that uses animated samples to convey uncertainty.
A scatter plot example with interactive legend and x-axis.
A searchable, stacked area chart of U.S. occupations from 1850 to 2000.
A labeled scatter plot of films showing Rotten Tomatoes ratings versus IMDB ratings.
A basic line chart example.
A scatter plot with trend line calculated via locally-weighted (loess) regression.
An example of a custom tooltip (on a map)
A nested bar chart example, with bars grouped by category.
Area charts of stock prices, with an interactive overview and filtered detail views.
A packed bubble chart.
An implementation of the classic video game Pacman.
Parallel coordinates plot showing 7 dimensions of automobile statistics.
Estimating the value of π via random sampling methods.
A basic pie chart example.
A simple platformer. WASD to move, shift to dash.
A population pyramid showing U.S. demographics from 1850 to 2000.
Area chart using density estimation to show a probability density or cumulative distribution.
A gallery of maps showcasing different cartographic projections.
A quantile dot plot conveying the uncertainty of bus arrival times.
A quantile-quantile plot example, comparing distributions by quantile values.
A radar chart example, showing multiple dimensions in a radial layout.
A basic radial plot that encodes two values as the angle and radius of an arc.
An example of a radial layout for a node-link diagram of hierarchical data.
A scatter plot with trend line calculated via user-configurable regression methods.
A re-orderable adjacency matrix depicting character co-occurrence in the novel Les Misérables.
A basic scatter plot example depicting automobile statistics.
A scatter plot of film statistics, with null values visualized along the axes.

a serpentine timeline. The serpentine shape can be an option for instances where an oblong canvas is not ideal. The shape can be customized using many of the signals below. Input bindings have been included for demonstration purposes

examples.example_name: Bar Chart Highlighting Values beyond a Threshold
examples.description: To create a bar chart that highlights values beyond a threshold, we use two `layer`s of `bar` marks. The lower layer shows all the bars while the upper layer shows bar with values above the threshold in red (`#e45755`).  We then `layer` a `rule` mark and a `text` mark over the bars to annotate the threshold value.
The production budget of the movie that has the highest US Gross in each major genre.

examples.description: The Trellis display by Becker et al. helped establish small multiples as a “powerful mechanism for understanding interactions in studies of how a response depends on explanatory variables”. Bump chart

Bar graph showing the best films for the year they were produced, where best is defined by at least 2.5 points above average for that year. The red point shows the average rating for a film in that year, and the bar is the rating that the film recieved.

A dot plot showing each movie in the database, and the difference from the average movie rating. The display is sorted by year to visualize everything in sequential order. The graph is for all Movies before 2019.

examples.example_name: Line Chart with Markers and Invalid Values

examples.description:
By setting the `point` property of the line mark definition to an object defining a property of the overlaying point marks, we can overlay point markers on top of line. 

 Notes: (1) This is equivalent to adding another layer of point marks. 
 (2) While `"point"` marks are normally semi-transparent, the overlay point marker has `opacity` = 1 by default.

examples.example_name: Line Chart with Stroked Point Markers
examples.description:
By setting the `point` property of the line mark definition to an object defining a property of the overlaying point marks, we can overlay point markers on top of line. Here we create stroked points by setting their `"filled"` to `false` and their `fill` to `"white"`. 

 Notes: (1) This is equivalent to adding another layer of point marks. 
 (2) While `"point"` marks are normally semi-transparent, the overlay point marker has `opacity` = 1 by default.

Though Vega-Lite supports only one scale per axes, one can create a parallel coordinate plot by folding variables, using `joinaggregate` to normalize their values and using ticks and rules to manually create axes.
A pie chart encodes proportional differences among a set of numeric values as the angular extent and area of a circular slice.

Layering text over arc marks to label pie charts. For now, [you need to add `stack: true`](https://github.com/vega/vega-lite/issues/5078) to theta to force the text to apply the same polar stacking layout.

This radial plot uses both angular and radial extent to convey multiple dimensions of data. However, this approach is not perceptually effective, as viewers will most likely be drawn to the total area of the shape, conflating the two dimensions. This example also demonstrates a way to add labels to circular plots.

Weekly weather data plot representing high/low ranges of record temperatures (light grey), average temperatures (dark grey), and both predicted and observed temperatures (black) for the given week. The first five days have high/low ranges of observed temperatures, and the last five days have ranges of predicted temperatures, where the upper barbell represents the range of high temperature predictions and the lower barbell represents the range of low temperature predictions. Created by @melissatdiamond.
